Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 03:15PM shiny wrote: I am glad you will be seen by the lymphoedema clinic. On your first visit which should be asap, ask to see the senior therapist and gie that most experienced person the full unabridge story of your rash, from the start. Don't loose that mobile number, and.. maybe get a second opinion, unless you 100 % trust this physician's experience. Good luck to you. Shiny
Posts.Title: Rash and fever? TerriD TerriD

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 02:56PM shiny wrote: try anyone who will act, bottom line it needs tending too. Go girl, Shiny
Posts.Title: Rash and fever? TerriD TerriD

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 02:18PM shiny wrote: Hi Terry, Very concerned for you reguarding that. I agree with everyone here that you should not leave this be and must get the correct diagnosis and treatment. I have just gone and got the  name of the med for you that I am meant to have with me at all times in case of any hint of infection etc on my side slightly affected by lymphoedema. In summer 2008 I had a very suden rash with feeling very ill and the kind of red hot rash pictured in the thread above, and some fever. I was prescribed "KLARICID 500"(clarithromycin and it started to work overnight and resolved things very quickly so I was very lucky. (I don't know if this is the one they would prescribe for all as I have a very delicate stomac and many allergies but it did do the trick very efficiently). BTW: I had no sign of a cut etc to show an infection introduction site. I am seen at the Lymphoedema clinic at one of the best cancer hospitals in Europe. I was told  to always have  a two week course of the meds in my posession and to take for any possible repeat of the symptoms as it is very important to limit any flares. So, based on this, I concur with the rest of the ladies that you need to be looked at and probably followed by a specialist lymphoedema clinic. I am very suprised at what you have been told so far, considering the risks if these docs are wrong, so do press on and I wish you the very best. Shiny
Posts.Title: Rash and fever? TerriD TerriD

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 08:49PM shiny wrote: Mia, glad you've got some great support from all the above. As you have the strength to be a super mom, you have the strength to tackle this bc too.  Try to be a super mom TO YOU this year, I always think that's good advice. Just helps you think about being kind, generous, patient with yourself as you figure out how to manage this one day at a time. It takes a while to transfer some of that great nurturing onto yourself when you are used to being the selfless mom, but honestly you need to. The kids are great though for keeping you in the now and positive. BTW: on the mastectomy front. I am 40 with young children,had a double mast with siea immediate reconstruction. Kids were fine with it, as I kept the info simple. They like my new boos with the happy face stitches. (2 circles where nipples were,1 circle around new belly button place, and 1 happy smile one( from hip to hip). I explained the whole bc thing as mum has bad "lumps"(cancer) that have to come out. I will have a very strong special potion (chemo) to help with the lumps. It's very good with the lumps, but will make my hair fall out, but that's OK because it will come back. Will you help me choose some nice hats? It will make me feel sick and tired some of the times but I am not scared as I know it is working to make me better. Mia,I hope that's not too much info. I just found it really helped me cope to know that the children were coping and the above was right for us. Hope some of that helps you. Sending you very strong good vibes and a great big hug. Shiny

Posts.Title: my beloved rooni has went home to the lord rooni janie44

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 05:10AM shiny wrote: Hi Tweeker, I have a high incidence of bc in family. I am not a BRCA 1 or 2 +(had test, but only showed a slight difference in my BRACA 2 gene which is not recognized as BRACA 2 +). Anyhow, I had left IDC but chose bilat mast with immediate recon for peace of mind, on at least a new local cancer. I have no regrets at all, one less thing to worry about, a very good symmetrical look (SIAE flaps) and natural feel. My cancer surgeon said that she supported my decision to have bilat,as in any woman with BC there is at least 30percent chance of a new BC and with my high family history of BC at around my age (40) that the risk was likely to be higher. That was good enough reason for me. Good luck with your decision. take care. Shiny

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 01:58PM shiny wrote: Hiya, I totally understand the worry. The onc just has to be thoughrough, as you would want him to be. I had 2 bone scans ofter my initialy staging one, both for scares, but turned out fine. But there is no denying that knowing it just coudl be "something" is a stress and a drain, no matter how optimostic you are, the waiting, sucks. I am 2 yrs post dx and at least I can say that with every scare, it takes a little less out of me, I am learning to just do the darn test and keep busy busy. What will be will be. Praying for a likely good ol, B9 for you. Take care, keep busy. Shiny
Posts.Title: Bone Scan somerset72 Shappy

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 01:00PM shiny wrote: Hi, I just seen your thread.  I am triple neg too, with young kids. Last July (see my signature for my stats) I had a enlarged lymph node biopsy scare. I was at the PS to have a routine post surgical check, I mentioned a swelling in my groin. They thought, just maybe a hernia or something, so sent me up for an ultra sound there and then. I was shocked when the ultra sound doc said, it's an enlarged lymph node, so as you are here, we shall do an immediate aspiration type biopsy. They had just installed a new ultrasound machine so the technician offered me a picture of said enlarged lymph node, and boy did I look at that picture over the following week. I spoke to a cancer nurse who did reassure me somewhat that it was much more likely that it was just "reactive" due to fighting an infection etc and not cancer, which just about made me breathe. It turned out to be fine. It still is swollen, up and down. I think I am used to it now and see it as my "super lymph node" the one that does all the work for the 16 others that are missing. It can be nothing and I pray that is the case for you. Great you are going it sorted now. And great you are giving a present to your angel, angels should be celebrated, they make such a difference! Shiny

Your familie's bond and love came accross with such clarity. The peace your dear wife felt surrounded by her most loving family in such a beautiful place, I can't imagine the pain and the strenght it took you, yet your family is clearly so rich in the best possible sense.  No doubt, your lovely wife will continue to impact and improve lives and shine her brilliant strenght and grace in many many lives in so many special ways;  As indeed, she did when she was here. I read her many times, and so many were inspired by her as you know and understand. Wishing you and your family much love and healing. Shiny
Posts.Title: River is an Angel now. Fitztwins susanmary

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2010 02:13PM shiny wrote: Eliza, So sorry you are going through this worrying time. Glad you found this site. It's a God send whilst you wait. There is not much to say at this point except. 1- You are absolutely doing the right thing calling your doc in the morning. ANY changes have to be investigsted. You are doing exactly the right thing, not to ignore it, and stay worried any longer. 2-If it is BC, it's always good to find out early. If it isn't BC and you know the majority of breast issues are not BC, then there  is no sense in prolonging your worry for nothing, as even the stress coming from your worry is not good for your body. So, Yes daaling, you are being a sensible, pro active, inteligant women, so don't let anyone "fob you off" until you are satisfied that this has been correctly and thouroughly checked out; By that I mean, mamo and ultra sound as a minimum from a specialized centre for bc, so that the people looking at the mamo or performing the ultrasound are experts. The majority of investigations will reveal B9 conditions of the breast, however, that is no reason to not fully investigate breast changes. You know your body, you've had 4 kiddos, you go get that peace of mind back. And take care, Wishing you all the best, you are doing the right thing. there is no point in guessing about things tonight, no crystal ball here, but making that call and following through is indeed, the best thing you can do for you. Keep poping into BCO and posting as much as you need through the waiting, you won't be alone here. Lots of support from lots of great ladies and lots of people in very similar position. All my best, hug. Shiny
Posts.Title: no lump, but dent (indentation) on one breast eliza0104 Jujube43

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 12:58PM shiny wrote: Hi Kathleen, I had about 1 year of chemo menopause as of the last round of my high dose FEC-T 100 back at the end of 2007. The oncs all said it was very unlikely that the periods would come back as I was 40 at end of chemo. Well, they came back, soon regular as clock work, now in the last 6 months they are unpredictable, all or nothing. Get very tired etc as if about to have one, then nothing, or  the oposite.  I would look into it, get a blood test, and thyroid test for starters, with your hormone levels (what ever the basics are for this stuff). It's always good to know, cause i firmly beleive that it's best to be aware of what is going on, so you can feel your best and act on anything that could do with some attention. Sure more insight will follow, all the best ! Shiny

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 12:46PM shiny wrote: Will be thinking of you too Kona, I will just add one of my fav treats I used to make when i lived "outwest" for the girls I worked with. If you want to try it out in your "I am sooooooooo worth it and deserving" decadent feast after tomorrow. Crush a pack or 2 of thin dark choc dry waffers or graham crakers with melted butter to make the base of a pie dish. pour in soft vanilla ice cream which you have laced with either Kahlua or a concentrate of strong coffee (diluted  "top quality instant" -if there is such a thing in a wee bit of boiling water). Pop into the freezer, when seriously hardened, overnight, put a thin layer on top of a dark chocolate icing, or coffee choc icing. ahhhhhh you can imagine cutting into this one with your mc dreamy or whom ever on your seriously wonderful fantasy beach. Thinking of you and sending you my best quality vibes right now. Shiny

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 02:52PM shiny wrote: Hang in there girl, You are not a member of the club yet, you might still not get your membership card. Your story sounds absolutely normal, that is your reaction, all of it going so fast whilst you are talking with yourself. It is great that they got on and took a sample right away. If you are destined to become a BC sister, then you are best to get on with "the programe" ASAP, then at least you will feel in charge again. This is a great place and I am glad you got on here before your results cause in many ways it is one of the hardest period. You could be a B9 lady, but if not, this is a great place to share and get support. For now, whether it is luxury ice cream, late "spring cleanning" silly movies, what ever do what it takes to keep busy and get yourself some sleep if you can whilst you wait for your results. I am 2 yrs out after double mast/recon and super high dose chemo, with 2 young kids and feel grateful as ever for everyday. Hang in there. hug Shiny

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2008 03:44PM shiny wrote: Hi, I was 39 last year when diagnosed (see my stats in my signature). I opted to have bilat mast for my peace of mind, with imediate reconstruction (SIEA flaps). I have a high incidence of BC in my family in younger woman, so I was told that I was possibly at an even higher risk for a second primary in either breast. My Cancer surgeon said that for any woman who has had a bc, there is an aprox minimum of 30% chance of second primary. With my quick aggressive type of bc first time around, that was good enough reason for me; I didn't want to have to keep checking and worrying about any little bump. Also, as I am triple neg, I felt this was the one thing, apart from loosing weight that I could pro actively do to "help myself". I have  not had to have any radiotherapy (which was nice as daily trips to hospital would have been tough on the kids and on the pocket book). I am very happy with my decision. I though very carefully about it and asked alot of questions. Take the time to really look into and understand your options and motivations. You can only do your best and what ever you decide, it has to be right for you.  Good luck, and hang in there! take care of you. Shiny

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 02:05PM shiny wrote: Sarmcl, The oncs will work with you if they can. They would rather you come to the "table" rested and most recognize the benefit of keeping  your holiday time "if possible". Just ask them about it asap,so you know where you stand. They should be able to give you a straight anwser based on your specific stats quite quickly. They will not put you at risk. There is often a few week's flexibility. I sure hope so for you. (In my case they delayed initial app due to a very special birthday celebration I was preparing for my daughter (4). In my friend's case, they delayed a few weeks so she could go on hols. It will all be based on your stats. You take care of you. Sorry you've had to become a member of the club. Big canadian hugg. You will find help and support here. take care of you. You are in charge. All my best.

Posts.Title: Going for followup mammogram today cp418 shiny

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 04:08PM shiny wrote: Hi there. Deep breath. So sorry for all the stress you are going through.I am under the weather today, but had to post "something" wilst you wait for more "switched on girls" to come and post. So, sorry for my choppy output but hope it still helps you a wee bit. Hang in there. 1- You have not had a definitive diagnosis. The biopsy will tell you more. 2-The waiting is THE most stressful and unsettling part of what you are going through. 3- It is near impossible not to worry yourself silly at this point and it is totally understandable, so try to get this core biopsy done ASAP as whatever you find, knowing what is in there will start to empower you. In the meantime, come here, you are not alone.  Also, try to find a good friend to share this with at the least, if that would help you. Eat ice cream, watch fav movies, do very very early spring cleaning.. whatever to keep you busy, so that you are not thinking of this every second, and it might help you get some sleep too. 4- The core biopsy is totally doable. There is a loud "bang" when they punch. I found that I was more comfortable with being told "3-2-1 punch", each time they punched, so that I expected the "bang" noise and it helped me stay calm. If you think it might help you ask them to count them down for you. I was chatting away to the friendly nurse the whole time, it was over fairly quickly and I just felt as if I was quite bruised after. 5- If you are diagnosed with BC. Glad you found this site, the ladies here are fab and will help you along. You are in charge, once you have a better understanding of what is being sujested for treatment and you have a good idea of what is coming hopefully you will start to feel more focussed on "getting on" with the treatment to make you better and that will give you a positive focus. Make sure you ask as many questions as you want and ask your "Cancer team" to repeat anything that is unclear to you until you understand it. Make sure you are happy with your team. 6- Take all the support that is offered to you and be gentle with yourself. Take good care of you. The waiting is the worse. You can do this. hug. Shiny
Posts.Title: going for biopsy jdemco Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 04:58AM shiny wrote: Hi Sue, Just a quicky from England to say. Hugg and hang in there. I just posted for the first time a week ago, it's been brilliant. You just keep remembering that you are here now and yes, 1 node is good. This is a great site and am sure that like me, you will find it rewarding to share your thoughts and receive and give support here.  Re: chemo, just enjoy crossing the doses OFF  as you go through your sets.  I found it helped especialy at the start of chemo to check symptoms of side effects on my "possible symptoms list". Then, even though I had a rough time on FEC-T, I knew that the symptoms would pass. And remembering what I was doing chemo for (for my good) was a good way off thinking about it, instead of dreading it.  I wish you the very best with it all. take care and be gentle with yourself (think of it like, this year you have to be a super mom, to yourself) all the best

Posts.Title: Fretting...Am I crazy? TexasMelody jalydiju

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 02:22PM shiny wrote: Estepp, Hi there. Yes, I remember the wait, what an intense time. There are alot of factors involved in deciding the protocol. Its hard to avoid trying to figure it out in advance of your results, but reading up here to get to grips with some of the terminology and possible scenarios AND also keeping yourself busy with non BC stuff (spring cleaning, fav film, exercise etc) will keep you going while you wait. Just remember, you may get a peachy result and that will be terrific. If it is BC, you will rise to the challenge and do what you have to do to manage it. I had FEC-T chemo 100 x 6 rounds for triple negative grade 3 BC with node involvement. My hair was my crowning glory, and yes I lost it all quick. I didn't even mind that much because I though, hey, this chemo is the best protection/defense available to me right now and side effects and all, I want the stuff! You get through it. I finished it in mid November and now my hair is 2 inch long and thick as ever. Hope you get a B9 result, if that is not to be, you do your best, be gentle with yourself, take the love and support of loved ones and you go girl, just go through it and whip that BC!  You stay in charge and ask as many questions of your doc team as you need until you understand enough to make your decisions on your treatment.  Take care, Shiny

Take care.  Shiny
